People are so worried about water where to get it and will it run out? The answer is simple as it's all around us in the air we breathe. They make a device now the can run off solar or normal electrical wall sockets called an Atmospheric Water Generator (AWG for short) They sell them here https://ecoloblue.com/ which take the moisture out of the air and condenses it into water then filters it. Much like how an A/C unit in your window drips humidity. It's the same kind of machine on a more refined scale. The home version makes up to 30L per day but they also sell and make indutrial versions that make 1000's of liters per day. They even have some videos where they plan to install huge AWG plants in dry arid regions to make water using sunlight. It was even featured on the new a number of times here's one https://youtu.be/WjpmjxVfQ1w and the follow up story here: https://youtu.be/25mJhbwG8_k (For some reason they do not include the fact that these units also sell with a solar kit so they are virtually cost free to operate and generate water) So the guy they interview is mistaken to say they cost a lot to run all the with electricity they draw.

From this distant vantage point, the Earth might not seem of any particular interest. But for us, it's different. Consider again that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there – on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.

The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that in glory and triumph they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner. How frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds. Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity – in all this vastness – there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.

The Earth is the only world known, so far, to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment, the Earth is where we make our stand. It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known.


-- Carl Sagan

I've personally limited my CO2 usage since around 13 years ago, I still use quite a bit, but I turn off the usage of unnecessary energy whenever it is not needed, you might consider this to not be enough, and to a degree I'd agree. Thing is, I can only do what I can afford to do, but this is also the point, many people think that they are being told to stop using energy alltogether whenever people mention climate change, that is not really it, it is A way, but the most useful way, would be to shift energy production to green alternatives, and to limit your usage where not needed, for example, do you need to let your television run while you sleep? Propably not, turning it off when asleep already cuts down your CO2 emissions by a small amount, if you do similar things all over, you can reduce your CO2 amount significantly.
People tend to think, that in order to change themselves or the world around them, they need to make drastic changes, while often times the most succesful methods, are to make small incremental changes, also those tend to be the most effective, as major changes are harder to implement.
So if you have some energy you use, that you don't need, and want to help the global situation, don't use it, also consider using chemicals and such which are less damaging to the world, rather than ones that cost a fraction less.

What can we change? Like literally, what do we need to do? So many people saying: "We need to change, we need to do something". What is that something? And I'm not talking recycling plastic bags, or turning off electronics you don't need, or taking public transportation instead of the car (although I'm still concerned whether that's actually better for the environment), cause I'm doing that stuff already. I mean serious changes.

The problem with issues of humans effecting the environment, like climate change, is that there's no clear outright solution, so people just argue of whats better and whats worse, and no one can make a decision. What needs to happen is the gathering of quantifiable data, and for someone to say, here's the options, here's what they'll take, and here's the effects, now choose. From this it could be deduced what method would be most beneficial, scientific issues should be tackled in a scientific and rigorous way, this is one of the reasons not having scientists in the government is such a bad idea, there are so many politicians who have degrees in law, which is very much a study of how to make good arguments, not solve problems (both are important- but you can't depend solely on someone who's just good at arguing). I know a lot of scientists don't want to be in the government, but that's because it's set up in such a way that relies on debate and those skills which are gained through learning politics and law, rather than scientific skills. It's almost as if you have to have a predetermined set of beliefs before you come into politics with left wing and right wing, you can't join a political party without that naming, it's incredibly unscientific, the scientific methods consists of a few simple and fundamental axioms, and deductions from those along with gathered data, the whole point is to avoid predetermined beliefs.
